item.title: matplotlib.pyplot
item.description: 1 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt Plotting with matplot

item.title: numpy
item.description: 1 import numpy as np np.arange() The np.arange() function generates a list of values from the lower to the upper value, separated by step.

item.title: Python
item.description: Python is a coding language. It has pretty intuitive syntax. Fun to use and play around with! Libraries Python has a variety of libraries of useful functions that you can import using the command import <library>.

item.title: Web Development Resources
item.description: Make the thing a link The thing itself is a link. Delightful. Skimmable. When you see the thing, it’s clear you can get to it.

item.title: Starship Troopers
item.description: Starship Troopers is a classic science fiction novel about the space military. It was one of the works that popularized power armor (which is kinda cool), and also one of many sci-fi works that focuses on conflict with alien species.

item.title: Building should be natural
item.description: Too often when we build things, we seek to impose some imagined order from the top downwards. We conceive a blueprint on paper, following some rules we have learned, and try to optimize the building.

item.title: patterns are made of spaces and events
item.description: Patterns are made of spaces and events. These cannot be separated from one another. Space gives rise to events, and events give context to space.

item.title: Patterns are shareable languages
item.description: If we think of a person’s collective knowledge of patterns like a language, then the patterns are words, patterns that connect patterns are grammar/syntax rules, and buildings and places are sentences.

item.title: The timeless quality distinguishes good buildings
item.description: All good buildings (and many other good works of design) share the same timeless (and nameless) quality. Think of the moments in your life where everything just felt “right.

item.title: The world is made of patterns
item.description: The character of something—a place, a tool, a person—is given by the events that occur within and around it most often.

item.title: There is no point in optimizing things that should not be done at all
item.description: There is nothing so useless as doing efficiently that which should not be done at all. —Peter Drucker A corollary to the [[notes/5_theory-of-constraints|theory of constraints]]: do not optomize things that are not worth doing.

item.title: Making symbolic links
item.description: 1 ln -s /path/to/file /path/to/link to include paths with spaces, enclose that folder in double quotes.

item.title: The Timeless Way of Building
item.description: Summary In The Timeless Way of Building, Christopher Alexander describes the (somewhat mystical) practices of making good buildings—buildings that promote use and life.

item.title: Biology is organized in hierarchies with emergent properties
item.description: [[notes/2_biology-is-the-study-of-life|Biology]] is organized into hierarchies. Molecules combine to form macromolecular proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and nucleic acids; these in turn build the organelles that then make cells; [[notes/2b_cells-are-units-of-life|cells make tissues, then organs, then organisms]]; organisms interact with their environment to form ecosystems.

item.title: Brevity is the soul of wit
Goals focus effort
item.description: Goals give our effort context and focus. They define an end and direct our actions to that end. If we don’t have goals, then we have no stopping points.

item.title: Problems are a type of goal
item.description: Problems [[notes/14_goals-focus-effort|goals focus effort]]—in this case, solving the problem or responding to it in some way. In the context of problems, consider that there are both [[notes/14a3_strong-link-problems-maximize-positive-outliers|strong-link problems]] and [[notes/14a2_weak-link-problems-minimize-negative-outliers|weak-link problems]].

item.title: Research and writing are two sides of the same coin
item.description: Research and writing are two sides of the same coin.1 Both require [[notes/15a_writing-well-takes-time|time]], clear understanding, and seek to communicate information. They rely on [[notes/15c_the-key-to-credibility-is-specificity|write about what you know]], and writing it well.

item.title: Science is a strong-link problem
item.description: Science is a [[notes/14a3_strong-link-problems-maximize-positive-outliers|strong-link problem]].1 It works by encouraging more outstanding results and positive outliers. That means we’re better off with more people doing science.

item.title: Strong link problems seek to maximize positive outliers
item.description: Strong-link problems describe situations where worth is determined by the best results. Contrast these with [[notes/14a2_weak-link-problems-minimize-negative-outliers|weak-link problems]], which work by curtailing negative outliers rather than maximizing positive ones.

item.title: The key to credibility is specificity
item.description: The writing that stands out most is that which draws on deeply personal experiences.1 It is writing that cannot be made from a simple formula.

item.title: We are not running out of ideas
item.description: We are not running out of ideas. If you look at all of the research and knowledge we’ve accumulated over the past millennium, it’s tempting to say that all of the easy things have been done—it’s only getting harder from here.

item.title: Weak-link problems seek to minimize negative outliers
item.description: Weak-link problems describe situations where worth is determined by the worst results. Contrast these with [[notes/14a3_strong-link-problems-maximize-positive-outliers|strong-link problems]], which work by maximizing positive outliers rather than curtailing negative outliers.

item.title: Writing Well
item.description: [[notes/15a_writing-well-takes-time|writing well takes time]] [[notes/15b_brevity-is-the-soul-of-wit|brevity is the soul of wit]] [[notes/15c_the-key-to-credibility-is-specificity|the key to credibility is specificity]]

item.title: Writing well takes time
item.description: Writing well, like doing anything, takes time.

item.title: Cells must organize themselves in space and time
item.description: [[notes/2b_cells-are-units-of-life|Cells]] must organize themselves in both space and time to respond to environmental cues and carry out the [[notes/2a_central-dogma-of-biology|necessary functions for life]].

item.title: Cloning
item.description: When you hear “cloning,” you might think of Dolly the sheep1 or the Star Wars prequels. But in [[notes/2_biology-is-the-study-of-life|biology]], cloning usually refers to [[DNA replication]] and gene expression for experiments.

item.title: Math proofs are data-less
item.description: [[notes/7_what-is-math|Math]] proofs are a sort of self-contained thought experiment. These logical proofs do not require data or experimentation; they only require a line of reasoning.

item.title: notes should be atomic
item.description: Atomic notes are self-contained

item.title: Personal information practices
item.description: There’s a lot of information out there. To make sense of it, it’s best to use some form of organization.

item.title: Resources for writing online
item.description: https://jvns.ca/blog/2017/03/20/blogging-principles/ Be honest about what you know Fact check your work (and correct it) Be positive Stick to your own experience Talk about things while they’re fresh in your mind It’s okay if not everyone likes it https://jvns.

item.title: The Color of Law
item.description: Summary Rothstein’s book is a fantastic rebuttal to basically everything I learned about segregation in my high school history classes. De facto segregation is a myth, and we can’t fight back against de jure segregation without a means of de jure integration.

item.title: What is a folgezettel/zettelkasten?
item.description: To be honest, I still don’t know how I got so much german in my notes, but it’s a thing now and it’s here to stay.

item.title: What is Math?
item.description: [[notes/7a_math-is-a-humanities|Math is a humanities subject]]. It is the study of numbers. It also might not be real. Some 2000 years ago, Plato the philosopher proposed that math revealed a sort of hidden reality of the world—a universal ideal a layer below what our experience.

item.title: Obsidian
item.description: Obsidian is a markdown editor. It allows you to connect notes using [[wikilinks]]. It has passable vim integration, very good customization through community plugins, and works well for keeping a permanent repository of notes.

item.title: Address bottlenecks to improve efficiency
item.description: The idea is to get the most out of the least work. The eighty-twenty rule suggests that [[twenty percent of the effort gets you eighty percent of the results]].

item.title: code should be modular
item.description: All good code should be modular. This allows it to be used and re-used in different scenarios. Like building blocks. Writing code is a bottleneck to software engineering.

item.title: Empire of Illusion
item.description: Context Hedges wrote Empire of Illusion during 2009, during the middle of an economic recession. Near the midway point of Obama’s second term.

item.title: Sort pages by date in hugo
item.description: A snippet to group things by date in a section. I use this to display things from the reading list, which makes it easy for me to see what I read and when.

item.title: Start here
item.description: Hello! Welcome to my giant stack of filing cabinets that I uploaded to the internet. If you’re reading this right now, it probably means that this is your first time here.

item.title: AlphaFold
item.description: AlphaFold is an awesome system for predicting protein folding. It works quite well and has some versions you can use on the web.

item.title: Biochemistry is the language of life
item.description: Biochemistry is the intersection of [[notes/2_biology-is-the-study-of-life|biology]] and [[notes/3_chemistry-is-the-study-of-matter|chemistry]]. It covers stuff from residues on protein structures to protein-protein interaction and all sorts of neat things.

item.title: Biology is the study of life
item.description: Biology is the study of life. It connects a wide range of research, from information on [[notes/2a3a_operon-model|genetic circuits]] to [[notes/2b_cells-are-units-of-life|cellular biology]] to ecology and [[notes/4_biochemistry-is-the-language-of-life|biochemistry]].

item.title: Cells are the atomic units of life
item.description: Omnis cellula e cellula. All cells come from cells. Such states cell theory, one of the key ideas in biology.

item.title: Central dogma of biology
item.description: The central dogma of [[notes/2_biology-is-the-study-of-life|biology]] is that [[notes/2a3_one-gene-one-protein|DNA]] is [[notes/2a1_DNA-transcription|transcribed]] into RNA, which is then [[notes/2a2_DNA-translation-makes-proteins|translated]] into amino acid chains that make proteins.

item.title: Chemical reactions are the core of chemistry
item.description: Chemical reactions are the core study of [[notes/3_chemistry-is-the-study-of-matter|chemistry]]. Reactions between atoms can produce entirely new substances with properties wholly different from others.

item.title: Chemistry is the Study of Matter
item.description: Chemistry is the study of matter. In a way, it’s a sort of applied [[notes/9_physics|physics]]. Chemistry deals with the properties of matter as it combines.

item.title: Circular permutation
item.description: The alternative approach to [[notes/2d1a_protein-domain-shuffling|domain shuffling]] is to reuse domains from the same protein, but in a different order. While this is much more difficult to do well than lateral domain shuffling, it can produce very interesting results (like circular fluorescent proteins1).

item.title: Cloning is the bottleneck of synthetic biology
item.description: [[notes/2d_synthetic-biology|Synthetic biology]] relies largely on [[notes/2d1_cloning|gene cloning]] to test various [[notes/2a3a_operon-model|genetic circuits]] in vivo. Depending on cloning strategies, it can take anywhere from several days to several weeks to get from design to data.

item.title: Complex systems are emergent phenomena
item.description: Complex systems are emergent phenomena. Thye come from a set of smaller subsystems. For example, this very folgezettel that I’m using right now to organize my notes is a simple system, but it grows more complex the more I work with it.

item.title: complex systems emerge from simple systems
item.description: All complex systems emerge from simple systems that worked first. This makes them a type of [[notes/1_emergence|emergent phenomena]].

item.title: Computer programming
item.description: Computer programming is everything that deals with writing code and functions for handling information in a computer. Computer programming is what I usually think of when I hear the words “[[notes/6_computer-science|computer science]],” but there are some differences between the two disciplines[[notes/6a1_code-should-be-modular|code should be modular]].

item.title: Computer Science
item.description: Computer science is the study of the foundations of information and computation. The instructions for processing and handling this information are explored in [[notes/6a_computer-programming|computer programming]].

item.title: DNA encodes genetic information
item.description: Deoxyribonucleic acid, or DNA, is the most important molecule in [[notes/2a3_one-gene-one-protein|genetics]]. It encodes the blueprint for making an organism, directly determining physiology.

item.title: DNA is translated into proteins
item.description: [[notes/2a1_DNA-transcription|DNA is transcribed into RNA]] using transcriptase in the nucleus of the cell. That RNA is then interpreted by ribosomes. Each triplet codon of the RNA translates to a specific amino acid, which is linked onto an ever-growing chain by a peptide bond.

item.title: DNA transcription
item.description: See also: [[notes/2a2_DNA-translation-makes-proteins|DNA translation]]

item.title: Fixing Workspaces Plus Plugin
item.description: From this discussion on github: I found an easy fix, while we wait for @nothingislost to handle this properly: Navigate to <vault>/.

item.title: gray-scott model
item.description: Equations1 The Gray Scott Model describes [[notes/2b2a_reaction-diffusion-systems-self-organize|reaction-diffusion systems]] using the following equations: $$\frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = F(1-u) - uv^{2}+ D_{u}\Delta^{2}u$$ $$\frac{\partial v}{\partial t} = -(F+k)v + uv^{2}+ D_{u}\Delta^{2}v$$

item.title: Lateral Domain Shuffling
item.description: Typical protein-based design strategies rely on breaking a protein down into individual domains. Modular domains can then be used to design new constructs and networks.

item.title: Life is an emergent phenomenon
item.description: Life is an [[notes/1_emergence|emergent phenomenon]]. It comes from many molecules and proteins coming together to form something that can organize its self in both space and time, and respond to environmental cues.

item.title: liquid-liquid phase separation
item.description: Liquid-liquid phase separation is a phenomena by which particles in solution group together and form “droplets” or puncta. This creates different “phases” of material within the liquid phase of the solution.

item.title: Living phenomena can be understood through cells
item.description: Since [[notes/2b_cells-are-units-of-life|cells are the atomic units of life]], studying cells reveals things that can be extrapolated upwards to more complex levels.

item.title: Logic
item.description: Logical, right?

item.title: Math is a humanities
item.description: [[notes/7_what-is-math|Math]] is a humanities. It sits very closely to philosophy, based on principles of [[notes/8_logic|logic]]. [[notes/7a1_math-proofs-are-dataless|Math proofs are data-less]], and (if sound) will always yield exactly the same conclusion.

item.title: Min System is a self-organizing patterning system
item.description: The bacterial Min [[notes/2b2a_reaction-diffusion-systems-self-organize|reaction-diffusion system]] is a regulatory system in certain bacteria that helps them to dynamically determine the center of the cell for placement of the division plane.

item.title: MinD
item.description: MinD a protein in the [[notes/2b2a2_min-system-self-organizing-regulatory-system|Min system]]. In the cytosol, it binds ATP and attaches to the cell membrane. There, [[notes/2b2a2_min-e-protein|MinE]] attaches to it and triggers MinD’s ATPase function.

item.title: MinE
item.description: MinE is a protein in the [[notes/2b2a2_min-system-self-organizing-regulatory-system|Min system]]. In the cytosol, it dimerizes with other cytosolic MinE. When it detects membrane-bound [[notes/2b2a1_min-d-protein|MinD]], it binds to it and stimulates MinD’s ATPase function.

item.title: Phenomena emerge from the smallest units
item.description: Emergence is when new properties come out of groups of things. These groups are often the atomic units of a particular field (atoms in [[notes/3_chemistry-is-the-study-of-matter|chemistry]], cells in [[notes/2_biology-is-the-study-of-life|biology]], people in civilization).

item.title: PyMol
item.description: Useful Commands Selection and Highlighting To select a specific peptide sequence, use the following command: 1 select pepseq <sequence> Use only single-letter amino acid abbreviations.

item.title: Reaction-diffusion systems self-organize in space and time
item.description: Reaction diffusion systems are a type of interaction between particles that can be described as both [[notes/3a_chemical-reactions|chemical reactions]] and diffusion. [[notes/2b2b_phase-separation|Liquid-liquid phase separation]] also adds an additional dimension to the reaction-diffusion system, as many types of patterns also have a sort of phase-separating component.

item.title: Selective pressure plus random mutation equals evolution
item.description: Evolutionary biology is the study of how the [[notes/2a3_one-gene-one-protein|genetics]] and physiology of a species change over time in response to evolutionary pressures.

item.title: tex-mex
item.description: Ingredients 1 lb. lean ground beef 1 chopped onion 1 chopped green pepper 1 bay leaf (or two) 28 oz stewed or diced tomatoes 1 can black beans 1 can pinto beans 1 can corn 1.

item.title: yeast are model organisms for biology
item.description: Yeast are model organisms in microbiology, since they are so well-characterized. Many strains exist ([[notes/2c2_saccharomyces-cerevisiae|Saccharomyces cerevisiae]] being one of the most well-known) and fulfill a variety of use cases.

item.title: Page lists
item.description: 1 2 3 4 {{ $section := .Section }} {{ range where .Pages "Section" $section }} <ul><a href="{{ .Permalink }}">{{ .

item.title: Replacement for hugo pagination
item.description: For replacing pagination in [[docs/hugo/hugo|hugo]]. See also [[docs/hugo/page-list|page-list]] snippet for hugo. a Sections Replace instances of: 1 {{ range .

item.title: Inspiration List
item.description: [[games/liars-dice|liar’s dice]] [[miscellaneous/xeno-series|Xenoblade Chronicles]] [[notes/2c1_yeast-toolkit|MoClo kit]] [[notes/11b_read-it-now-or-never|read it now or read it never]] [[notes/10_digital-gardens|10_digital-gardens]]

item.title: Liar's Dice
item.description: Liar’s dice is a game that my friends and I picked up a year or so ago to pass the time as classes were ending.

item.title: Perfect First Drafts
item.description: “Every first draft is perfect, because all a first draft has to do is exist.” —Jane Smiley https://joelhooks.

item.title: Read It Now or Read It Never
item.description: I stopped using my link inbox some time ago. Every time I use it, I run into the same problem: I funnel too many things into it and I don’t want to let go of any of them.

item.title: What is a digital garden?
item.description: In short, a digital garden (or personal wiki or hypertext farm or what-have-you) is a way of displaying your thinking. It’s like working with the garage door open.

item.title: Xenoblade Series
item.description: The Xeno- series (also sometimes called the Perfect Works saga) is a set of videogames that starts with Xenogears (1998). I’ve only played the Xenoblade Chronicles games and the relevant DLC.

item.title: Bistable Switch
item.description: ![[media/bistable-switch.svg]] The bistable switch is a type of [[notes/2a3a_operon-model|operon]] that consists of two inhibitors. Because each one downregulates the activity of the other, this results in two stable phenotypes.

item.title: Hugo
item.description: Hugo is a static site generator written in go. This wiki runs on Hugo. It’s a little more complicated to use than Jekyll, but it’s much faster and seems to work better for development.

item.title: MoClo Yeast Toolkit
item.description: The Modular Yeast Toolkit1 (YTK) is a set of design principles and parts for construct design in yeast (and particularly [[notes/2c2_saccharomyces-cerevisiae|S.

item.title: Music
item.description: Exercises [[notes/12b_shifting-exercises|Shifting exercises]] [[notes/12a_backwards-practice|Practice backwards]] [[notes/12c_slow-fast-practice|Practice slow, then fast]]

item.title: Operon Model
item.description: Developed by Jacob and Monod, the operon describes methods of gene regulation and control. Since [[notes/2a3_one-gene-one-protein|one gene encodes information for one protein]], there’s a nice one-to-one conversion between a section of DNA and cellular tools.

item.title: Practice backwards
item.description: When approaching a difficult excerpt or passage in music, instinct tells us to practice it over and over again from start to finish.

item.title: Practice slow, then fast
item.description: Doing things fast is fun, but moving quickly without practice leads to mistakes. The best way to avoid this is to go slowly first.

item.title: Protein domain shuffling
item.description: Protein domain shuffling is a [[notes/2d1a_cloning-is-the-bottleneck-of-synthetic-biology|cloning technique]] used in [[notes/2d_synthetic-biology|synthetic biology]] design. It usually focuses on shuffling around functional domains of a protein to try to create new chimeric proteins that fulfill a particular use case.

item.title: Tuscan Vegetable Soup
item.description: Like minestrone soup, but on steroids. Ingredients 1 can cannellini beans 1 Tb olive oil 1/2 large onion, diced (~1 cup) 2 carrots, diced (~1/2 cup) 1 small zucchini, diced 1 clove garlic, minced 1 Tb chopped fresh thyme (or 1 ts dried) 2 Tb chopped fresh sage (or 1 ts dried) 1/2 ts salt 1/4 ts ground pepper 4 cups chicken or veggie broth 14oz diced tomatoes 2oz baby spinach leaves (~2 cups) Instructions Mash half of the beans in a small bowl.

item.title: Naming style guide
item.description: Names are important! Especially when it comes to files and organization. Taking a little bit of time to establish a consistent syntax/style for naming makes it much easier to find things when you look for them later.

item.title: Saccharomyces cerevisiae
item.description: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker’s yeast) is a well-characterized organism in biology. I’ve started working them in the summer of 2023, and I find them very friendly (especially compared to the fussiness of metazoan tissue culture).

item.title: Synthetic biology seeks to make biological tools
item.description: Synthetic biology is a field of science that focuses on creating biological systems for fun and profit. It is closely intertwined with [[notes/2_biology-is-the-study-of-life|biology]] and [[notes/2a3_one-gene-one-protein|genetics]], and particularly the [[notes/2a3a_operon-model|operon model]] (which is the basis of synthetic genetic circuits).

item.title: Yeast Vectors
item.description: Yeast have three primary types of [[notes/2c3_yeast-vectors|expression vectors]]: integrating plasmids, cen-ARS plasmids, and 2-micron plasmids. Genes of interest must be cloned into these for yeast experimentation.

item.title: The Archive Undying
item.description: Emma Mieko Candon’s The Archive Undying is a bizarre, semi-apocalyptic, scrap-punk sort of story. The narration swaps between first-, second-, and third-person, sometimes reaching all three within a single chapter.

item.title: The Bluest Eye
item.description: The Bluest Eye by Tony Morrison is a a book about racist distortions of beauty. That’s an oversimplification.

item.title: Parable of the Talents
item.description: If [[books/butler_parable-of-the-sower|Parable of the Sower]] was haunting, then Parable of the Talents was terrifying. It’s a book about Lauren’s work with Earthseed in the midst of the regression of “Christian America.

item.title: Moby Dick
item.description: Full disclosure: everything I knew about Moby Dick before reading this novel came from Bone by Jeff Smith. I did not know what I was in for.

item.title: The Joy Luck Club
item.description: The Joy Luck Club was a fantastic read. Amy Tan’s vivid stories about grandmothers hit home. Like most of the books I’m reading right now, I heard about it a few years ago in one of my English classes from another student.

item.title: A Prayer for the Crown-Shy
item.description: A Prayer for the Crown-Shy is a worthy sequal to [[books/chambers_a-psalm-for-the-wild-built|A Psalm for the Wild Built]]. This book, too, reads like a fairy tale, though this is more of a “stranger in a strange land” situation.

item.title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
item.description: In The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, Rebecca Skloot—alongside Deborah Lacks and the rest of the Lacks family—tells the story of Henrietta Lacks and the HeLa cell line that was made from her.

item.title: The Future Is Disabled
item.description: The Future is Disabled by Leah Lakshmi Piepzna-Samarasinha reads like a good kick in the teeth. Their writing feels like someone is talking to you.

item.title: Jellyfish Age Backwards
item.description: I picked up this book because I wanted to learn about jellyfish and some of the biochemistry behind ageing. What I got was a mix of pop science around ageing.

item.title: The Mimicking of Known Successes
item.description: Malka Older’s The Mimicking of Known Successes is a nice, if relatively straightforward, mystery novel. It’s also a romance. The setting is neat, but nothing about this book really stuck out to me.

item.title: How the Word Is Passed
item.description: How the Word Is Passed is a great introduction to the history of systemic racism. Clint Smith tells the story of racism through places, in a sort of museum-learning style.

item.title: Foundation
item.description: Isaac Asimov’s Foundation is a sci-fi novel that follows statistician Hari Seldon and his disciples as they work to mitigate a galactic disaster.

item.title: The Mythical Man-month
item.description: I would have gotten more out of this book if I were a software engineer or full-blown computer programmer. Much of the contents went over my head, since I’m not a member of that target audience.

item.title: We Could Have Been Friends, My Father and I
item.description: Raja Shehadeh’s We Could Have Been Friends, My Father and I is part-memoir, part-history, and part-biography. In it, Shehadeh chronicles his father’s long fight for Palestinian liberation.

item.title: Wild Massive
item.description: Wild Massive by Scotto Moore is like The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy but the universe is inside a building and features amusement parks.

item.title: A Psalm for the Wild-Built
item.description: I think I have a new favorite book. Becky Chambers’s A Psalm for the Wild-Built is a beautiful book about a tea-brewing therapist in a post-cataclysm world going on a road trip with a robot.

item.title: Stolen Focus
item.description: Stolen Focus sounds like a self-help book, but it isn’t. Johann Hari takes a systems-first approach to understanding distraction, rather than centering the individual.

item.title: The Rock Eaters
item.description: The Rock Eaters is an anthology by Brenda Peynado. The stories within range from magical realism to speculative fiction to science-fiction.

item.title: Killers of a Certain Age
item.description: If I had to describe this book in a single sentence it would be “It’s like John Wick but with middle-aged women.

item.title: Tidesong
item.description: Wendy Xu’s Tidesong is a graphic novel about a girl who goes to study magic with her great-aunt. The artwork is beautiful.

item.title: Invisible Man
item.description: This book. Oh boy this book. Ralph Ellison is a phenomenal writer. I loved reading Invisible Man. It’s a brilliant story, but to simply call it a novel is reductive.

item.title: Animal Farm
item.description: Animal Farm, by George Orwell, is a satirical novel about fascism and communism. Framed as a fairy tale about a group of animals that overthrow their farmer, Animal Farm chronicles the farm’s slow descent into tyranny as the pigs gain more and more power as the governing body.

item.title: The Emperor of All Maladies
item.description: The first of Siddharta Mukherjee’s three books (the others are [[books/mukherjee_the-gene|The Gene]] and [[books/mukherjee_the-song-of-the-cell|The Song of the Cell]]), The Emperor of All Maladies is a masterfully-written chronicle of cancer and oncology.

item.title: Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
item.description: One of my friends reminded me that this book existed last week. I borrowed it out as an ebook this morning and read it on the bus.

item.title: Hooky
item.description: Hooky by Míriam Tur is a cutesy book about a pair of siblings trying to get through the year after accidentally missing the bus to their boarding school.

item.title: On Writing Well
item.description: In his book On Writing Well, William Zinsser outlines a set of best practices and techniques for writers of all stripes and skills.

item.title: Entangled Life
item.description: Mushrooms have been making the rounds on the internet and in pop culture. At the Renaissance Fair last year, I saw more than zero people dressed up as mushrooms.

item.title: The Butchering Art
item.description: The Butchering Art is another fantastic work of scientific and historical journalism, chronicling the transformation of Victorian medicine through the life of Joseph Lister—the surgeon who pioneered sterilization via carbolic acid.

item.title: Hood Feminism
item.description: Hood Feminism is a collection of essays about feminism, racism, poverty, and change. Each essay focuses on a different issue: hunger, racist beauty standards, the systemic exclusion of non-white needs from mainstream feminism, and other topics.

item.title: Song of Solomon
item.description: Toni Morrison is a fantastic author, and Song of Solomon is not an exception to that rule. Like in her other works, Morrison fills every sentence in Song of Solomon with nuance and symbolism.

item.title: The Gene
item.description: At first glance, The Gene book is hefty—and it’s certainly not a novel. It took me a couple months to finish this one.

item.title: The Song of the Cell
item.description: My parents gave me this book as a Christmas gift. I had been working in a lab with cells and all sorts of other things for about six months by then, and I was (and still am) convinced that research was the place to be.

item.title: Sapiens
item.description: Sapiens by Yuval Noah Harari has some problems.
